Posts.Content: Like many here I found it far more difficult to choose the option best for me than I anticipated, but I chose Da Vinci. Kaiser offered three choices: Da Vinci, EBRT, or a combined EBRT with Brach. I found EBRT and/or combined with Brach to be most tempting, but also perplexing given others experiences with their providers. First, for radiation Kaiser does not worry about interference from bowel content or use balloons. The oncologist said it only requires 16 to 32 oz of water to be consumed prior to treatment. The treatment is fast, suggesting it would take less than 20 minutes. Second, Kaiser said that aside from surgical tagging the prostate with gold markers, it will only require 27 (or 28?) sessions - claiming that the reason many do 44 sessions is to create more billable treatments to insurance companies. Last, Brach plus EBRT sounded most intriguing, taking only 3 weeks. In any event I decided Da Vinci worked best for me. It will leave me the option of radiation at a later date (if needed) and probably avoid the need for Lupron which might add to my already significant fatigue problems. But at least I got the "choice" behind me.

Posts.Content: I can now understand why this process is one of learning by experience, unfortunately the lessons learned usually apply to the next person. In retrospect, had I carefully thought through the implications of the advice and literature provided, perhaps I might have chosen a better treatment choice. Anyway, let's start with the living in the present, and the great news today. First, I am recovering without complications and tomorrow will have my catheter removed. Recovery has not been fun, with much discomfort and initial movement impairment, but 8 days after surgery I finally feel like my old self in energy and mobility (except for the annoying urine bag and periodic catheter discomfort). And because I didn't need more than 4 or 5 oxycodone pills, I have some left for a future emergency. Second, my surgeon sent me my pathology report. She was very happy and says it was the best possible outcome. My Gleason 8 score DROPPED to G7, the margins were clear, there was no cancer found outside the small tumor which was wholly located within the prostate. The only expected (but disappointing) news is that the nerve, on one side, could not be spared. Here is a synopsis: C. PROSTATE, RADICAL RESECTION - PROSTATE AND SEMINAL VESICLES - PERMANENT: PROSTATE GLAND: Radical Prostatectomy [version 6/2017] -AJCC 8th Edition Staging TUMOR Histologic Type: Acinar adenocarcinoma Primary Gleason Pattern: Pattern 4 Secondary Gleason Pattern: Pattern 3 Total Gleason Score: 7 Grade Group 3: Gleason Score 4+3=7 Percentage of Pattern 4 (%): 90 Tumor size (dominant nodule, if present) Greatest Dimension in Millimeters (mm): 15 Extraprostatic Extension (EPE): Not identified Urinary Bladder Neck Invasion: Not identified Seminal Vesicle Invasion: Not identified Lymphovascular Invasion: Not Identified Perineural Invasion: Present MARGINS: Uninvolved by invasive carcinoma Benign prostate glands present at surgical margin LYMPH NODES Regional Lymph Nodes: Number of Lymph Nodes Involved: None identified. Number of Lymph Nodes Examined, Specify number: 24 PATHOLOGIC STAGE CLASSIFICATION (PTNM, AJCC 8TH EDITION) Primary Tumor (pT): pT2: Organ confined Regional Lymph Nodes (pN): pN0: No positive regional nodes ADDITIONAL FINDINGS Additional Pathologic Findings: High-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PIN) Nodular prostatic hyperplasia Best TUMOR Block(s) If Further Studies Are Needed : C4 Three, while all of this is good news and may mean a cure upon more reflection I am wondering how I might have benefited if the biop G8 score had been G7. I had been desiring a Cyber-Knife treatment (although my Uro does not like them) and based my choice based on the fact that I had a G8 score. Then I remembered a thread on whether or not biop's are reliable Gleason score measurements? In fact, was all of this necessary and how could have known which treatment were both optimal and minimally disruptive to my life after treatment.? As it is incohentence will be an issue for many months (I assume) and erections are history. I am happy...yet...somewhere in this there seems to be some kind of regret to. Strange, no?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH Hi Mark, I would have no treatment regrets at all with such post-treatment results. Without surgery, you would NEVER have known you were only a G7 and would have lived in future fear in the false knowledge that you were G8. But now you know, without a doubt, that you are (WERE!) a G7. I see nothing to be regretful over as you have a pathology report that could almost not be any better. As Djin noted, you can have erections with just one nerve, so you should make a complete recovery both in the sexual and prostate cancer departments. Congratulations!! Chuck True, I would have wondered after radiation treatment for many years. Thanks for you advice...many here are very glad you lend your wisdom and expertise.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Narnar Got the results of my 3 month PSA and it remained steady at 0.1. The news made for a great day. That is really great news. I am still learning about prostate cancer but I noted that your PSA rose from 11.5 to 62.4 in six months; as I have a Gleason score of 8 on a core and (a month ago) a 9.4PSA, it is encouraging to see the effectiveness of your treatment. It also makes me think I should be retested to see how fast mine is rising. If you had not had a second opinion (and therefore had missed the small spot) do you think that would have changed treatment? I'm beginning to wonder if a 2nd opinion is routinely warranted in CT and Bone scans.

Posts.Title: 5 years post RALP

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH Hi Mark, I moved your post (and the replies) to its own thread so you can get more attention. As the others noted, a PSA of 9.5 does not necessarily signify prostate cancer. And, even if you do have PC, this PSA number does NOT necessarily mean that it is beyond control. Just be sure to visit with a highly experienced urologist and also be prepared for a recommendation to have a biopsy. It is HIGHLY likely that you are either okay now -- or WILL be just fine after any treatment that might be required. Stick with us & we'll help you every step of the way. Chuck Thanks to everyone for their advice and kind thoughts (and moving my concern to a separate thread). My health problems for many years has focused on cardio and diabetes, a problem that runs in my family. However, no one has had a prostate problem that I know of - although my father passed from cancer of the esophagus (he was a mostly life long heavy drinker and smoker). Naturally I am berating myself for not having monitored my testing better, and in delaying an over-health checkup for several years. So I will relax a little and see what the followups show. However, I do want to move the testing along promptly and should their be even a modest chance, I will encourage my doctors to consider removal sooner rather than later. Finally, I'm a bit confused on the blood test markers. In addition to PSA I understand their is a PC3?
Posts.Title: How Bad is a PSA over 9?

Posts.Content: Hi, I am new here. Yesterday I received a lab test back that stunned me. For many years I have had been treated for adult onset diabetes and high blood pressure (along with meds for cholesterol and lipids). I was so focused on those problems and the related tests that for several years (or more) I went without a PSA test; so I really don't know what my original baseline was after 2011 or so (when it was normal). Today, at nearly 67 my PSA came back at 9.5 and will be seeing my GP in a few days for followup. I don't even know if it is possible to have a 9.5 without cancer, but I am a nervous wreck. It would seem that one should not delay action and while I think a PC3 test and imaging might be useful, would it not be safest to have an ASAP removal of my prostate and lymph nodes? I really don't care if I have ED, but I fear I have waited to long. Will the doctor insist on a full battery of tests before such a procedure? Also, Id appreciate any feed back on MRI vs. color Doppler and whether or not both would compliment each other?

Posts.Title: Best Surgical Options Still Seems Unclear

Posts.Content: Perhaps I am getting ahead of myself, after next weeks body scans are done I expect that I will be presented with several options (radiation or some kind of surgery). However, after doing some research, I am not clear which kind of surgery is recommended for which kind of circumstances. While I get the recovery pros and cons, I don't have a sense as to what a highly localized Gleason 8 tumor (a single biop core of 14 taken) might require. Is there any reason that any of the following surgical options would less effective for a single tumor than another? If not, then wouldn't the least invasive option, with the fewest side effects, be preferred? And would that not be Da Vinci? - Da Vinci Robotic Prostatectomy/Robotic-Assisted Laparoscopic Radical Prostatectomy (RALRP) - Laparoscopic Radical Prostatectomy (LRP) -Radical Perineal Prostatectomy (Open) -Radical Retropubic Prostatectomy (Open) Anyone's thoughts on these choices is appreciated. I am sensing (but not sure) my provider might not wish to use Da Vinci, for reasons that are unclear.

Posts.Content: The wisdom of sharing depends on the kind of people you share with. At one time it was considered bad form to share personal and intimate details of one's life - today it is usually different. All my friends are understanding, none reject me because I have/had prostate cancer. Some are curious, some are not. Only one is a pain in the butt because he is insistent on me taking supplements, drinking health juices, and the like. And he is also a pain because he cannot handle my sense of humor over the disease, as if I am offending karma to speak with levity. So you have to decide. And, by the way, I see nothing wrong with you asking about the reasons for his unwillingness to seek treatment, and expressing your opinion in a caring way. If he wants to go his own way - let it go and give him emotional support.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH Just to be sure I said it correctly, it is possible to use radiation as a salvage treatment if recurrence takes place after surgery. But the reverse is not true -- it is SELDOM possible to use surgery for salvage treatment if radiation fails. The reason is that the external beam radiation treatments tend to build up scar tissue around the prostate bed -- which makes it extremely difficult for a surgeon to access the prostate through all that scar tissue. I also recall one of our members mentioning that his doctor told him that trying to do surgery on an irradiated prostate is like trying to work with a rotted peach. In any case, there are only a few surgeons who will attempt salvage surgery because of the complexity involved. But also remember that I am not a doctor (and don't even play on on TV), so these are questions to ask both a surgeon and a radiation oncologist. Now I understand. Thx

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic Hi Mark. You said Am I correct to say the +2 yrs ADT was only (definite) for the RT option? I've seen studies that would indicate that for high-grade cancer accompanied by negative path findings at the time of RP, radiation had slightly better long-term results. However, the trick may be predicting whether or not the PCa is prostate-contained. I opted for surgery for two reasons (1) I felt given my 6-month checkup schedule and the recent negative imaging (CTs, bone scan & X-rays), my G10 was caught early and contained; (2) With colon cancer in the family (both sides), and for other reasons, I wanted to avoid both the short- and long-term adverse effects of RT as well as the chance of a second primary tumor of the bowel or bladder. In other words, I wanted to bet on the chance to get all the cancer out at the time of surgery (knowing ART or SRT could be in my future). So far it looks good (I have my 1 year check-up tomorrow), but you don't know what the future will bring. (My PCa was downgraded to a G9, the path report was very good, and the Decipher results were that my PCa is/was low risk for mets.) At the moment my only discussion over options with my uro was a quick email exchange of a couple of sentences - so I will have a clearer understanding tomorrow when we confer. But yes, in that dialog he did present it as surgery vs. radiation and ATD for two years. For me this won't be an easy choice because even if there are only slight differences in 10 yr survival rates, I am trying to envision the short and long term difficulties with pain, side effects, etc. Moreover, while I feel fit enough for surgery I am trying to envision the challenges to everyday living during recovery (eg. grocery shopping, paying bills, etc.). Radiation does not sound as difficult, but the thought of having to commute everyday for two months and spend a half day in an office is not my cup of tea. I guess I need to research what a year after surgery would be like, and the long term effects of radiation (future incontence?). ED is not an over-riding concern as my diabetes has already eliminated much of my sex drive and functionality.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic Hi Mark. You said Am I correct to say the +2 yrs ADT was only (definite) for the RT option? I've seen studies that would indicate that for high-grade cancer accompanied by negative path findings at the time of RP, radiation had slightly better long-term results. However, the trick may be predicting whether or not the PCa is prostate-contained. I opted for surgery for two reasons (1) I felt given my 6-month checkup schedule and the recent negative imaging (CTs, bone scan & X-rays), my G10 was caught early and contained; (2) With colon cancer in the family (both sides), and for other reasons, I wanted to avoid both the short- and long-term adverse effects of RT as well as the chance of a second primary tumor of the bowel or bladder. In other words, I wanted to bet on the chance to get all the cancer out at the time of surgery (knowing ART or SRT could be in my future). So far it looks good (I have my 1 year check-up tomorrow), but you don't know what the future will bring. (My PCa was downgraded to a G9, the path report was very good, and the Decipher results were that my PCa is/was low risk for mets.) At the moment my only discussion over options with my uro was a quick email exchange of a couple of sentences - so I will have a clearer understanding tomorrow when we confer. But yes, in that dialog he did present it as surgery vs. radiation and ATD for two years. For me this won't be an easy choice because even if there are only slight differences in 10 yr survival rates, I am trying to envision the short and long term difficulties with pain, side effects, etc. Moreover, while I feel fit enough for surgery I am trying to envision the challenges to everyday living during recovery (eg. grocery shopping, paying bills, etc.). Radiation does not sound as difficult, but the thought of having to commute everyday for two months and spend a half day in an office is not my cup of tea. I guess I need to research what a year after surgery would be like, and the long term effects of radiation (future incontence?). ED is not an over-riding concern as my diabetes has already eliminated much of my sex drive and functionality.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Groot Hi Mark, Given my situation was similar to yours, thought I would share my experience. My biopsy came in as a 4+3=7 and had a positive DRE, so urologist was clear action was required. I was 58 at the time, and was advised I could go either way (surgery vs. RT). If I was older, he would have advised RT, younger would have been surgery. After doing much homework (as you're doing now), I opted for surgery. One of the reasons I went this way was to hold onto the option of future RT to the pelvic area, if needed (i.e. for PC BCR or other pelvic issues like colon, etc). RT technology is constantly improving, so this may not be a factor for you, easy enough for you to discuss with the experts. ... One regret I have is I did not have genomic testing done. If you follow DJ's sticky you can get a good idea of the information you can gain, another topic worth discussing with the experts. Hang in there, keep doing your homework, and best of luck to you with whatever course of action you choose! Please keep us posted. Thanks, everyone's shared experience helps me in my decision making. Genome testing could be useful I suppose, so I'll read the sticky. Also, I need to get the biop report.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Konna Thank you so much for your replies. It helps a great deal just knowing you're not alone. My father's prostate gland is showed to be just lightly enlarged, just over 40cc. I do not know yet the exact percentage of the cores or if there are any "4" in there, because our urologist talked to me via phone and just told me that the cancer's gleason score is a 6.we have an appointment on Thursday to discuss it thoroughly. When I know something more I will inform you. What worries me the most right now is that extremely rapid rise of the psa in just two weeks! From 27 to 43!! Our urologist said that he has never seen it before and I think that also doesn't stick to that gleason score of 6. Excuse any grammatical etc mistakes, I am from Greece. Thank you again for sharing your stories with me and for your advises and optimism which is so important for me right now. Welcome to the group and as for grammatical (etc) mistakes don't worry, you write better than most native speakers of English. As for his follow-up PSA scores, they do seem to be too fast but if he got one after the biopsy my uro says they are unreliable for sometime - so much so he wouldn't give me a followup PSA after my biop. There are others here far more informed than I, but remember a G6 is low risk. The next step will likely be scans to see the extent of the cancer outside the prostate, if any. Finally, remember than prostate cancer is one of the most treatable cancers there is . Even my odds, at G8, are 99% survival at 5 years, and 95% survival at 10 years. So hang in there, and take it one step at a time.

Posts.Title: Dad's just been diagnosed..

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Roadranger82 I will be having RALP in 3 weeks, starting to roundup everything I need to have on hand. Which Depends products should I get for after cath removal? the flex fit or real fit? I will probably get some guards too, for when I progress to those. do I need some kind of donut to sit on? I see some of them are shaped, any recommendations on those? I already have some sweat pants that snap up the side for post op, thought those would work well with the cath. what else? I like all of the advice here. In my experience: 1) The trip home with a leg bag was uncomfortable, I didn't have a pad or donut. 2) I should have had a recliner setup, but opted to use the bed. However, other than the first night the bed was okay. 3) The bucket by the bed is a great idea - on the other hand I did fashion a long cord to loop around my shoulder in order to carry the bag just above the floor. Only problem was the cord slipping off my shoulder. 4) I didn't shower or move my leg attachment for nine days - I was always concerned about the cath moving "in" or "out" too far (an unnecessary worry in retrospect). 5) I stocked up on frozen and refrigerated foods. Forget cooking - use the microwave. Do ALL grocery shopping before the surgery and make sure to cleanout your fridge of old stuff that might spoil during recovery. 6) Make sure the antibiotic Vaseline like cream is handy - your penis will thank you. 7) Make sure you have refills for any other meds you take - running out of those meds in the middle of recovery is a vexation you don't need. Make sure you take your stool softener. I felt constipated all the time and at one point opted for a laxative - ask the doc what kind of laxative is okay. 9) The cath is always uncomfortable so finding the right position to sleep will require experimentation. 10) I used flex-fit depends and they worked okay for me. The day after cath removal I gushed like a firehouse. Make sure you have your depends (at least two) with you. Finally, I bought a couple of pair of quick dry hiking pants (nylon) that wick away moisture. I made sure they were baggy, and very light-weight. What a blessing - I am now wearing this kind of pant as a regular. Very comfortable. Best of luck.

Posts.Title: Getting ready for RALP, what do I need onhand?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Southsider Dad's numbers and testing results just don't seem to add up logically. Maybe you are omitting a detail or didn't hear something, but I'd definitely be looking at a 2nd opinion here. People can live for a long, long time with metastatic prostrate cancer, and your father's case doesn't sound like it would be that aggressive, but then it didn't sound like it would create mets either. About 20 years ago, I met a young man who was about 40 or so, and he told me his story. He wasn't feeling well, he went to the hospital with a pneumonia, and they gave him a complete workup. The doctor comes to his room to give him the verdict, showed him the X-rays and explained the spots on his bones were mets. He had lung cancer and it had already spread and was incurable. Needless to say, he was pretty bummed out, but got up to leave the hospital. But they convinced him to stay to take a needle in the chest and drain his thoracic cavity. Afterwards, the took another X-ray- and then walked back the diagnosis, changing it to rheumatoid arthritis. Mistakes are made. Things aren't always what they appear to be. True. My sister in law went to one hospital and they told her that x-rays indicated cancer, and recommended immediate exploratory surgery. She went to a second hospital and they said it was just gas. Turned out to be just gas.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by yolli71 Hi All, Hope everyone had a great Thanksgiving! So I posted my experience the other day regarding my first week post-RALP. Now that I've had my catheter removed for a few days, I was hoping some of you could answer some questions I have. … Nothing your experiencing sounds unusual. I found/find my urine flow a bit unfocused and messy when standing. I also find extra contractions will empty the bladder. And I did urinate four or five times a night, although that has reduced to three or so. And until recently I also had an unbearable and sudden urgency but four weeks after cath removal that has lessened some (though not entirely). Things don't feel "normal", and there are odd feelings in my urinary track. Not pain, just a kind of "hollowness". Aside from incontinence, my biggest frustration is with simple urination which is often difficult to direct and tends to spray. Not sure if that is normal.

Posts.Title: Catheter removed....now what?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by OldTiredSailor Adenocarcinoma Gleason 7 ( 3 + 4 ) Grade Group 2 pT3a pNo 20% of gland involved bilaterally EPE: Present, Focal Left Posterior Apex Margins: Involved by invasive carcinoma 2mm Unifocal Gleason 3 Positive Margin: Left Posterior Apex 2mm Alll other margins: No invasion Perinuereal Invasion: Present 4 Lymph nodes examined - No involvement Seminanal Vesicle Invasion: Not identified Curiosity is that the path report identifies a 30cc prostate (ellipsoid) and 38cc prostate (bullet) with a weight of 35 grams. The DRE characterized my prostate as "small" and the MRI and TRUS calculated it to be 18cc. The surgeon looked at the report for a couple minutes and said: "well, looks like you might need radiation therapy but let's wait 6-weeks for a PSA test." Memorial Sloan Kettering nomogram gives me a 31% chance of BCR within 5-years, 48% chance of BCR within 10-years with NO radiation but a 98% cancer specific survival rate at 15-years with NO radiation. My whole attitude has changed dramatically since the RALP. The worry about side effects and the future no longer concern me. It is like "I've been through the worst now, so a little radiation is no big deal and a 98% survival rate at age 86 is a big deal." A question on my mind, before seeing my uro, is whether or not surgery is necessary if I am going to need radiation anyway (which they probably wouldn't know till AFTER a surgery)? And I realize that anyone can beat themselves up for having not been more pro-active (I know I do) but it is what it is. Still 98 percent over 15 years is great odds, and who knows what new treatments and drugs will be added to the tool-kit over that time. Keep us posted on your recovery - it is likely I'll be in surgery by Oct 1 and doing the same followup.

Posts.Title: Two Quick Questions regarding PSA test

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ljames Left Anterior -- 10mm of 17mm, 59% involved, Gleason 7. No perineural invasion or extraporstatic tumor Lesion #2 -- 15mm of 17mm, 88% involved, Gleason 7. Perineural invasion is not present. No definite extraprostatic tumor is seen, however there is a tumor adjacent to skeletal muscle and extremely close to adipose tissue. Right Anterior -- 2mm of 13mm, 15% involved, Gleason 6. Perineural invasion not present. No extraprostatic tumors. --- Obviously, I'm concerned most about the Lesion #2 and possible involvement outside of the prostate. What are the chances the tumor is cancerous? And am I looking at a minimum of surgery or radiation for Gleason 7? I got these results over MyChart and won't talk to my Uro until Thursday. I wasn't worried before these results, but now I'm pretty scared and can use some help interpreting these results. Need help until Thursday. Most others here know more than I, but it's not worth being scared. Your PSA was rather low (mine was 10.4) and Gleason 7 is at intermediate risk (mine was Gleason 8, high risk). And unlike me, your DRE was smooth. None the less someone here ran my numbers through a calculator and I had a 99 percent chance of survival in 5 years, and a 96 percent survival rate at 10 years. Your preliminary estimates have to have been better than mine. Most likely you will have a bone and body scan done, to confirm what is already almost certain (there is no spread) and then be given a choice on either surgery or radiation. I don't see a "wait and see" option to be realistic at this point, but with a PSA as low as yours I am uncertain. If not, you might be eligible for "cyber-knife" which is a highly focused and localized radiation treatment for intermediate and low risk cancer - the treatment is only 3 to 5 "zaps" and its over. Five year survival rates are identical to more extensive treatments. Honestly, the biggest hassle I have encountered is making choices and dealing with treatment side effects, not the cancer. Posts.Title: Biopsy Results - 2x Gleason 7 +. Need some help.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH Hi Mark, Were you referring to the color of the urine in the catheter bag? If so, do not be worried about it being dark. Actually, it is SUPPOSED to be a dark color in the days right after the surgery. There is bleeding involved as the sutures heal around the newly reconnected urethra. The color will gradually become lighter as the week goes on. If it is sufficiently lighter, after the week has passed, they will know it has healed enought to remove the catheter (which is totally painless). Hang in there in the meantime. It's good to hear that she says everything went fine. This means she expects no surprises in the pathology report. You'll probably get all those details when you see her. Good luck!]Chuck Thanks. Ya I guess I thought the urine bag was looking lighter for awhile - it only been two days since the surgery (on Tuesday morning, I write this Thursday evening). I guess I will have to wait for more information. But I am glad its over (at least for now).

Posts.Title: My first week since da Vinci...

Posts.Content: I have yet to update my profile. However, a week after I was told by my provider (Kaiser Oakland) than November 20th was the first open date, a sudden vacancy opened up. My anxiety has been such that I just wanted move forward so I took the October 9th slot for Da Vinci surgery with the original surgeon I had interviewed. Four days to prep (and cleanup private affairs) was hectic but she and her team did it without a glitch. She said everything looked good but she could not spare the nerve on one side due to the location of the tumor (which I anticipated.) Since then I have recovered ok, and thought my urine had cleared up from the blood. However, today it looked dark pinkish yellow again - when should I expect to see clear urine? Days? Weeks? Also, I am returning to her office in a week for catheter removal and, if the pathology report is done, discuss the results. If the path report is not done when I see her, what should I asked her after the surgery? I kinda felt like she was in a hurry during her hospital visit and I didn't take the opportunity to ask what "just fine" meant.

I found/find my urine flow a bit unfocused and messy when standing. I also find extra contractions will empty the bladder. Posts.Title: Catheter removed....now what?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ljames Left Anterior -- 10mm of 17mm, 59% involved, Gleason 7. No perineural invasion or extraporstatic tumor Lesion #2 -- 15mm of 17mm, 88% involved, Gleason 7. Perineural invasion is not present. No definite extraprostatic tumor is seen, however there is a tumor adjacent to skeletal muscle and extremely close to adipose tissue. Right Anterior -- 2mm of 13mm, 15% involved, Gleason 6. Perineural invasion not present. No extraprostatic tumors. --- Obviously, I'm concerned most about the Lesion #2 and possible involvement outside of the prostate. What are the chances the tumor is cancerous? And am I looking at a minimum of surgery or radiation for Gleason 7? I got these results over MyChart and won't talk to my Uro until Thursday. I wasn't worried before these results, but now I'm pretty scared and can use some help interpreting these results. Need help until Thursday. Most others here know more than I, but it's not worth being scared. Your PSA was rather low (mine was 10.4) and Gleason 7 is at intermediate risk (mine was Gleason 8, high risk). And unlike me, your DRE was smooth. None the less someone here ran my numbers through a calculator and I had a 99 percent chance of survival in 5 years, and a 96 percent survival rate at 10 years. Your preliminary estimates have to have been better than mine. Most likely you will have a bone and body scan done, to confirm what is already almost certain (there is no spread) and then be given a choice on either surgery or radiation. I don't see a "wait and see" option to be realistic at this point, but with a PSA as low as yours I am uncertain. If not, you might be eligible for "cyber-knife" which is a highly focused and localized radiation treatment for intermediate and low risk cancer - the treatment is only 3 to 5 "zaps" and its over. Five year survival rates are identical to more extensive treatments. Honestly, the biggest hassle I have encountered is making choices and dealing with treatment side effects, not the cancer. So hang in there, the needless fear is the worst of it...not the cancer. PS - I ran your PSA, G7, and 3 of 18 cores as "cancer" through the calculator. You've got a 99 percent 15 year survival rate and chances are good for no follow-up treatment. You might want to plug-in your own numbers: https://www.mskcc.org/nomograms/prostate/pre_op

Posts.Title: 48-hours post RALP

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Kendadi I had some days where the urine in my catheter bag would turn pink. This seemed to coincide with increased physical activity (walking). When I questioned this, I was told it was normal, as only one or two drops of blood would color the urine. If it turned bright red, I would contact your urologist. My panic was premature. This morning I noted that it is lighter than yesterday. So in spite of my prior reading of others experiences, I have been pained by bloating and seeming (probably illusionary) strong feelings of constipation. I was feeling great by the time I was released (comparatively speaking) so I was not prepared to feel worse when I came home. Oxycodone has been my pain killer of last resort and it has surprised me that I have needed it several times to deal with the belly and constipated discomfort. This morning I feel much better but I have not had a bowel movement in nearly two days (other than tiny releases of gas). I am wondering if a suppository laxative would be safe?

Posts.Title: Recovering from Robotic Procedure, a question

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Kpminn Recently DX’d PSA 12.7 Gleason score 8 (4+4) Bone scan and CT scans no evidence of metastatic spread Consulted with radiological oncologist and urologist and have decided to have robotic radical prostatectomy. I am scheduled for Jan 29, 2019 and am concerned about the wait. Should I be? Is it a no hurry, no worry situation. The waiting has been the hardest part of this whole process; Appointment, tests, and waiting for results has been difficult . I’m a Vietnam veteran and have had agent orange exposure. Also Dx’d with CLL in 2014, currently stage zero, no symptoms. My care is through the VA and I have been very satisfied thus far. Thanks in advance! Keith Sorry to hear your news, but as I was G8 I thought I'd share my own experience. I wanted it as fast as possible. My GP to Uro referral (Kaiser Permanente) was the next day because I told my doctor I'd take any uro who had an opening. At my Uro appointment he told be to sign up for a biop, which I discovered was backlogged for more than a month. I told them I'd take any uro doing a biopsy, and any cancellation. They had me come in the next day (a cancellation). A few weeks later (after the path report came back) I went for the usual scans (nothing found). I must have finished in record time, only to discover they like to wait 2 months after a biop before surgery. My GP tells me not to worry, even G8 gives me many months to decide my treatment plan. It took me several weeks to decide, and by then the uro who did robotic surgery was booked up for nearly two months. Once again, I got on a cancellation list and within ten days an opening was available at the last minute - I took it. I must have broke some kind of record within the system, from biop to surgery was two months and five days. Surgery went well, with best possible outcome. Margins, seminal invasion, lymphs, extensions, all good. They caught it early enough to be self-contained and wholly within the prostate, and in just one spot. The lesson is to get it done as soon as practical. It may not make a difference physically, but until you do it the mental stress of not knowing will take a toll. Additionally, I found that any lack of diligence on my part could have created serious delays (I let my surgeons calendar fill up while I was trying to decide which treatment to have). Anyway, it looks like you already have this rolling, so my advice is not really needed. But once you do it, you will be so glad its over with. That alone is worth prompt treatment. Good luck, best wishes. Mark H.

Posts.Title: Got My 6-week post RALP first test - not sure what it means...

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F Hi Mark H.! Be happy with this result. It means your PSA is considered to be "0!" Congrats & Welcome to "Club Zero! Simple arithmetic indicates the worst case scenario is: at least > 99% of the PSA generating cells have been removed. I don't see any valuable clinical information that can be derived from a 6 week post RP PSA using a standard PSA methodology. (except if the result is > 0.1) The "benchmark" post RP PSA typically is the 3 month value. Most URO Surgeons look for "< 0.01ng/ml" at 3 months. Of course, this requires an ultrasensitive PSA Methodology. Discuss with your URO Surgeon if you should test via uPSA at 3 months. Based on a 1/2 Life of approx 2.5 days, ALL 6 week post op uPSA levels should be < 0.01 at 6 weeks IFF 100% of PSA generating cells were removed. IMO, uPSA should be limited to those with elevated risk of recurrence who plan to commence Salvage Radiation (SR) as early as possible. uPSA can generate unnecessary "Dreaded PSA Anxiety" from clinically insignificant fluctuations in results. For now stay focused on achieving 100% recovery! Keep active, stay healthy & keep us updated along the way. MF Thanks, and I looked at your own experience as a guide. After 77 months post op you remain effectively zero. You are right, no reason to "sweat it" if and until there is something contrary to expectations.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Kpminn Recently DX’d PSA 12.7 Gleason score 8 (4+4) Bone scan and CT scans no evidence of metastatic spread Consulted with radiological oncologist and urologist and have decided to have robotic radical prostatectomy. I am scheduled for Jan 29, 2019 and am concerned about the wait. Should I be? Is it a no hurry, no worry situation. The waiting has been the hardest part of this whole process; Appointment, tests, and waiting for results has been difficult . I’m a Vietnam veteran and have had agent orange exposure. Also Dx’d with CLL in 2014, currently stage zero, no symptoms. My care is through the VA and I have been very satisfied thus far. Thanks in advance! Keith Sorry to hear your news, but as I was G8 I thought I'd share my own experience. I wanted it as fast as possible. My GP to Uro referral (Kaiser Permanente) was the next day because I told my doctor I'd take any uro who had an opening. At my Uro appointment he told be to sign up for a biop, which I discovered was backlogged for more than a month. I told them I'd take any uro doing a biopsy, and any cancellation. They had me come in the next day (a cancellation). A few weeks later (after the path report came back) I went for the usual scans (nothing found). I must have finished in record time, only to discover they like to wait 2 months after a biop before surgery. My GP tells me not to worry, even G8 gives me many months to decide my treatment plan. It took me several weeks to decide, and by then the uro who did robotic surgery was booked up for nearly two months. Once again, I got on a cancellation list and within ten days an opening was available at the last minute - I took it. I must have broke some kind of record within the system, from biop to surgery was two months and five days. Surgery went well, with best possible outcome. Margins, seminal invasion, lymphs, extensions, all good. They caught it early enough to be self-contained and wholly within the prostate, and in just one spot. The lesson is to get it done as soon as practical. It may not make a difference physically, but until you do it the mental stress of not knowing will take a toll. Additionally, I found that any lack of diligence on my part could have created serious delays (I let my surgeons calendar fill up while I was trying to decide which treatment to have). Anyway, it looks like you already have this rolling, so my advice is not really needed. But once you do it, you will be so glad its over with. That alone is worth prompt treatment. Good luck, best wishes. Mark H.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by RobLee Do not despair. I was G8 also, but with six positive cores - two of them 100%, and my PSA was 25, five months before surgery. Currently there is no evidence of disease, though I cannot be sure until after the HT has worn off in a couple of years. It has been a struggle, but it can be beaten. The scans will not eliminate the possibility of spread, as they are not that sensitive. But they will pick up if your case is seriously advanced. But I believe you are probably safe. Good luck with your path results. Thank you so much for your words of encouragement - all are welcome but to hear from someone who had more 100 percent positive cores and a PSA of 25 is very encouraging. I think the shock of a Gleason 8 was what knocked me for a loop. I am crossing my fingers that the scans will be negative and that I can immediately pursue whatever course is best (frankly I'd like Da Vinci but the "experts" will likely give the best advice). Again thanks.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ASAdvocate Mark, You do not have a death sentence. Either surgery or radiation can cure a Gleason(4+4) patient. Some recent studies are showing dramatic improvements in survival rates when both regular radiation and a brachytherapy boost are used. But, that is getting into treatment choices, and you need to have a couple more tests before you start consulting with the doctors who can treat you. A caution: there are three types of surgery and five types of radiation available to treat you. You may need to speak with practitioners of several to get comfortable with your future direction. It's confusing, but its better to have choices than not. Thanks so much...I am laying with the usual thoughts. It will take time to absorb and deal with it - again so many thanks.

Posts.Title: Significant rise in PSA

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by SubDenis Last night I had a long chat with a friend, whose dad has bad blood cancer. The topic of fear came up and we spent quite a bit of time discussing how fear can cloud reality. Some years ago, a friend shared with me about another disease I have a useful tool. Ask yourself two questions when you are fearful. What do I know and what do I think? Fear is often triggered by what we think not what we know. For many, it launches us into projecting the future and often it is dark future. However, we can focus on what we know which is more a cognitive process based on reality, which can lead to a more rational assessment of our current condition and the next steps we need to take, which can help us lead a more peaceful life today. Being in today is the goal, in my opinion. My experience with PC for the last almost 18 months were periods of shock, confusion, fear, understanding, decision making, treatment, and many more days of peace since treatment. I continue to find talking with other guys with PC very helpful. The gift of sharing your experience and letting newer guys know these phases are normal is a gift to self and to them! In the field of Alcoholism, there is a common belief that it is a three-fold disease of mind, body, and spirit and that a threefold recovery is needed. I suggest this is not too far off for us with PC. For most of us there are few body symptoms but once diagnosed many of us are challenged trying to understand, trying to make decisions, feeling alone at times, etc. I practice sharing, meditating, and trying to be there for other guys as part of my way of dealing with this disease and find it uplifting. I also continue to study this disease to be armed with facts. I have one friend with G9 who a great inspiration to me, as he goes through his road of treatments. I hope I give him some comfort in our sharing. I doubt that I will ever think getting PC was a good thing but clearly, there have been benefits of friends, of a self-awareness of how I need to show up to my family and friends, and a peacefulness most days because my clear goal is to live life today to the best of my ability. So today let’s choose life and continue to support each other! I could not agree more. The day I was told (over the phone) by my uro that my biop came back G8 I was dazed...almost disbelieving - I was living in the future, as if I were to die shortly. Slowly I began to deal with it after folks on this board provided a light and instead of dyeing a thousand deaths, I decided to live in the present. As researched, and my uro became more encouraging, I felt much better - especially after treatment. I ran the calcs on survival rates and I realized that most likely I would be dyeing of some other cause - so its back to the mundane life of bills and future plans (I realized I couldn't spend all my savings in a year, given that I may have a long life). Today, after surgery I feel back to emotional normal. So live in the moment - not the regrets of the past or the imagined fears of the future.

Posts.Title: Choose life over fear

Posts.Content: Hi all, Your encouragement has been a life raft but, again, I am feeling overwhelmed by the results of my biopsy. The results are in and my uro called to inform me the bad news, and (we shall hope) mitigating news. Of the fourteen cores examined, thirteen had zero cancer, no trace. However, the 14th core, taken from a small firmness found on the DRE showed it to be totally cancer. The Gleason index is 8, meaning its high risk. I'm devastated. The uro is guardedly hopeful and said "if I had to bet on it" because my PSA is only 10ish, and from the DRE and zero cancer in all the other cores, the tumor is highly localized and treatable. On the other hand, they are scheduling an MRI and CAT to make sure it has not spread elsewhere - if it has I feel I am on the clock. The uro did not want to offer any percentages on whether or not it has spread, but repeated that chances are it is a highly localized kind (so far) and that is has not spread elsewhere. I'm praying that my uro's informed guess is correct, but it will be several more weeks till I am tested and all the results in. I feel like I am waiting a death sentence. Right now I am staying a friends house to avoid being alone - the waiting is (as you all know) torturous. Mark H.

Posts.Content: Frankly, at my G8 score and the surgeon's inability to spare the nerve on one side, I kinda expected some follow-up salvage radiation therapy for me (its not uncommon). It does not bother me if it happens, EXCEPT the idea of Lupron is unwelcome. It's bad enough that erections are now very unlikely but to add in something that causes more fatigue (I am already a very low energy person) seems like a double whammy. So try to see the silver linings. If either of us half to do some radiation, so be it. Let's look forward to finishing it off and should, some five to ten years hence another kind of treatment is needed then (if anything) the options will have increased. In the meantime I'm going enjoy my coffee, good cooking, and the view from an RV I purchased.

Posts.Title: How Bad is 9-10 has now some very discouraging results.

Posts.Content: Frankly, at my G8 score and the surgeon's inability to spare the nerve on one side, I kinda expected some follow-up salvage radiation therapy for me (its not uncommon). It does not bother me if it happens, EXCEPT the idea of Lupron is unwelcome. It's bad enough that erections are now very unlikely but to add in something that causes more fatigue (I am already a very low energy person) seems like a double whammy. So try to see the silver linings. If either of us half to do some radiation, so be it. Let's look forward to finishing it off and should, some five to ten years hence another kind of treatment is needed then (if anything) the options will have increased. In the meantime I'm going enjoy my coffee, good cooking, and the view from an RV I purchased.
